message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about seed dispersal mechanisms. Seeds that stick in the fur of an animal will hitch a ride on that animal and be transported to a new location. Option (B) is incorrect because if the seeds fell back off immediately, they would not be able to disperse to new areas. Option (C) is incorrect because seeds in an animal's fur cannot sprout roots; they need to be in contact with soil for germination to occur. Option (D) is incorrect because the question does not mention anything about the seeds being unable to germinate; it only focuses on their ability to stick and hitch a ride on the animal.

This question requires some basic understanding of seed dispersal mechanisms. When seeds stick to the fur of an animal, they are able to "hitch a ride" and be transported to new locations. This allows the seeds to be dispersed away from the parent plant, increasing their chances of germinating and growing in a different area. Option (B) is incorrect because the seeds do not immediately fall back off. Option (C) is incorrect because roots do not sprout in the fur of the animal, but rather when the seed reaches the ground. Option (D) is incorrect because the seeds have the potential to germinate and regerminate in a new location.

This allows the seeds to spread and potentially germinate in a different environment. Option (B) is incorrect because if the seeds fell back off immediately, they would not be effectively dispersed. Option (C) is incorrect because roots do not sprout in an animal's fur, but in soil or other suitable substrates. Option (D) is incorrect because seeds that stick to an animal's fur can still germinate and regerminate in a new location.
